stories.text:
I have lots of stuff (various small equipment, cables, sharpies, small screwdriver, velcro, ...) that is scattered across my apartment.

If I had a house, I could devote space on my garage to gather all of that, but this is more complicated in an appartment (I do not have a spare room).

Do you have some clever strategies (boxes, labels, ...) that ideally force you too keep all this organized?
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you organize your “useful stuff” in an appartment?
Fully Sharded Data Parallel: Faster AI Training with Fewer GPUs
Apple removes ‘Fakespot’ app from iOS App Store following Amazon request
Show HN: Unavatar.io – Get unified user avatar
Down on 'The Farm': Learning How to Spy for the CIA (1980)
The Oberon+ parser, code model, compiler and IDE
Drone swarms smell trouble and could save lives

stories.text:
OOf, I'm dreading the critiques (ironically) but would love your input on our idea.

Do you care too much what people think about you/your project/your ideas?

Do you STOP doing fun things you enjoy because of how it looks or how it'll be interpreted by others? Even though you know deep inside literally no one is really paying attention to what you're doing?

Do you NOT go to movies alone, restaurants alone, have inhibitions in talking to customers because of fear or rejection, and what people will think of you?

There is an evidence based of techniques to alter your behavior with cognitive therapy. We propose such a 8 week bootcamp course (weekly lessons and exercises) to reduce this as much as possible.

My co-founder (a psychologist with expertise in behavioral change) and I (a physician) are considering whether people would find this useful.
stories.title: Ask HN: Could you critique the idea? (Newbie)
